public interface IItemHandle

Common protocol for auditable and versionable item handles alike. A handle is used to reference a particular item, or, in some forms, to reference a particular state of a particular item.

Item handles and items can only be created or retrieved from a repository while the client is logged in. When the client logs out, all objects that they obtained while logged in must be considered invalid. It is unspecified whether these objects come back to life, so to speak, if the client logs back in.

Speaking informally, items are objects that are stored in the team repository. Each item is something that has a unique identity, a fixed item type, and some states. Each item is identified by its item id (a 128-bit universally unique identifier, or UUID). Each item has a fixed item type . A few item types are built in to the foundations of the team repository. The team repository can be extended with the definition of additional types of items. The state of an item is the data that it recorded for that item. The state of an item can change over time. Recording the state of an item is what takes up the space in the repository.

These concepts are mapped to API interfaces as a pair of interface hierarchies, one for item handles and the other for the item states.

  • An IItemHandleis an item handle, and records an item id and type. These object can also carry a state id, in which case they are state handles. All item handles are typed.
  • Use IItemHandle.sameItemId(IItemHandle)to compare whether two item handles refer to the same item in virtue of having the same item id.
  • An IAuditableHandleis a handle to an item of one of the auditable item types. This is a subtype of IItemHandle. IItemHandle.isAuditable() returns true only for auditable item types. Any IItemHandle for an auditable type can be safely downcast to IAuditableHandle.
  • An IUnmanagedItemHandleis a handle to an item of one of the versionable item types. This is a subtype of IItemHandle. IItemHandle.isUnmanaged() returns true only for versionable item types. Any IItemHandle for a versionable type can be safely downcast to IVersionableHandle.
  • Each built-in item type has its own specific handle interface; e.g., IContributorHandle. Any IItemHandle can be safely downcast to its particular handle interface.
  • An IItemis an item state, and records the all the attributes and properties of an item. IItem extends IItemHandle, reflecting the fact that a state also carries the item id, item type, and state id. This allows an item state to be used where only an item handle is expected/required.
  • An IAuditableis a state of an item of one of the auditable item types. This is a subtype of IItem and IAuditableHandle. Any IItem for an auditable type can be safely downcast to IAuditable.
  • An IUnmanagedItemis a state of an item of one of the versionable item types. This is a subtype of IItem and IVersionableHandle. Any IItem for a versionable type can be safely downcast to IVersionable.
  • Each built-in item type has its own specific state interface; e.g., IContributor. Any IItem can be safely downcast to its particular state interface.
  • Objects implementing this interface are generally not canonical, and cannot be reliably compared with ==.
Note that although a state can always be cast as a handle, the converse is not generally true: a handle need not be a full state. Only handles that answer true to IItemHandle.hasFullState()can be safely downcast to state interfaces.

Design note: Note that equals() has no special semantics for item handles (i.e., it's just Java object identity). This means that expression like team.getMembers().contains(contributor) do not work as you might like. Use sameItemId() when searching for duplicate items with the same id as a given item.

Terminology: There is obviously a close relationship between an item handle and the item that it refers to. Where there is no risk of confusion, we drop the word "handle" and simply talk of items directly.

Since:
0.5

Method Detail

getItemId

UUID getItemId()
Returns the item id of this item. The item id gives items their identity.

Returns:
the item id; never null

hasStateId

boolean hasStateId()
Returns whether this item has a state id and is therefore capable of being used to reference to particular state of the item in the repository; in other words, can also be used as a state handle.

Returns:
true if this is a state handle, and false if it just has enough information to identify the item but not an particular state

getStateId

UUID getStateId()
Returns the id of a state of this item. The state id is used within the repository to identify the different states of an item.

A newly-created item may or may not have a state id; clients must not make assumptions either way.

Returns:
the state id, or null if none

sameStateId

boolean sameStateId(IItemHandle other)
Returns whether this item and the given item are objects representing the same state of the same item in the repository (that is, both have the same item id). If one of the other does not have a state id, this method returns false. Also returns false if other is null.

Note: This method cannot be meaningfully used to compare working copies, since working copies have no state id.

Parameters:
other - the other item, or null
Returns:
true if the items have the same item ids and non-null state ids, and false if other is null or the items have different item ids, different state ids, or no state ids

getItemType

IItemType getItemType()
Returns the type of this item.

Returns:
the item type; never null

getOrigin

java.lang.Object getOrigin()
Returns the origin of this item handle. The component client implementation is responsible for tagging its items with the proper origin. The item origin should have sufficient information to allow refreshing/refetching the item.

The component client API methods that tag items with an origin are responsible for documenting that fact.

Returns:
the origin of this item or null if unknown

isImmutable

boolean isImmutable()
Returns whether this item handle is immutable.

Returns:
true if this is an immutable item handle, and false otherwise

makeImmutable

void makeImmutable()
Marks this item handle as being immutable. Calling this method will not enforce immutability of the item handle. One must call IItemHandle.protect() to enforce the immutability of the item handle.

Once, immutability is enforced, calling any method that modifies the item handle, will cause an IllegalStateException to be thrown.

protect

void protect()
Enforces the immutability and working copy rules on items and item handles.

See Also:
IItemHandle.makeImmutable(), IItem.getWorkingCopy()

sameItemId

boolean sameItemId(IItemHandle other)
Returns whether this item and the given item are objects representing the same item in the repository (that is, both have the same item id). Also returns false if other is null.

Parameters:
other - the other item, or null
Returns:
true if the items have the same item ids, and false if other is null or the items have different item ids

hasFullState

boolean hasFullState()
Returns whether this represents a full state of the item. A full state is one where some of the state's property values are available to the client. The client can modify a full state and save it back. If an object answers true to this method, IItemHandle.getFullState()will return non- null; equivalently, this object can be safely cast to a state (IItem).

A newly-created item is also considered to be a full state which the client happens to be in the process of formulating from scratch.

Returns:
true if the item is a full state, and false otherwise

getFullState

IItem getFullState()
Returns the object representing the full state of the item, or null if this is just a handle. The handle can have a state id and is still only considered to be a handle to the referenced current state in the repository and not a full state. Note that server/repository is not contacted; a result is only available if the state had already been retrieved (or the item is in the process of being created).

If the item handle has an associated full state, the item returned is always identical to the receiver (the receiver is an object that implements both IItemHandle and IItem).

Returns:
the full state of the item, or null if this item is just a handle without state information (other than perhaps a state id)

isAuditable

boolean isAuditable()
Returns whether this item handle is for an auditable type of item. This method returns true if and only if this item handle can be successfully cast to IAuditableHandle.

Returns:
true if this is an auditable item, and false otherwise

isUnmanaged

boolean isUnmanaged()
Returns whether this item handle is for an unmanaged type of item. This method returns true if and only if this item handle can be successfully cast to IUnmanagedItemHandle.

Returns:
true if this is a versionable item, and false otherwise

isSimple

boolean isSimple()
Returns whether this item handle is for a simple type of item. This method returns true if and only if this item handle can be successfully cast to ISimpleItemHandle.

Returns:
true if this is a simple item, and false otherwise

getAdapter

java.lang.Object getAdapter(java.lang.Class clazz)
Returns an object that adapts this item to the given class. The result can be cast to clazz. Depending on the type of item involved, the result may or may not be identical to the receiver.

This method is used to get at the special API for the item when possible.

Pass EObject.class to get reflective access to the EMF underlying object. From the EMF object one can navigate to the EMF class to discover all structural features of this kind of object. Use EObject.eGet/eSet(EStructuralFeature) to access the attributes on the item in a generic manner.

The ground rules for accessing the underlying EMF objects:

  • The client may cast an object of an auditable item type to IAuditableHandle; if it has full state, it may be cast to IAuditable.
  • The client may cast an object of a versionable item type to IVersionableHandle; if it has full state, it may be cast to IVersionable.
  • When there are locally-available client side representations for a particular item type, the client may cast an object of that item type to the corresponding Java handle type documented with that item type. For instance, a contributor item can be cast to IContributorHandle; and, if it has full state, it can be cast to IContributor.
  • The name of the EMF class of the object bears the name acknowledged in the item type. That is, this.eClass().getName() matches this.getItemType().getName()[ + " Handle "]. Similarly, this.eClass().getPackage().getNsURI() matches this.getItemType().getNamespaceURI().
  • The exact set of structural features inherited from the EMF classes named "ItemHandle", "Item", "Auditable", and "SimpleItem" are internal, undocumented, and subject to change. While a client is free to display these structural features for debug purposes, they must not make assumptions about their continued existence or usage.
  • The client must not explicitly modify (eSet) any of the structural features inherited from the EMF classes named "ItemHandle", "Item", "Auditable", or "SimpleItem". These are reserved for use by the implementation of the Client API.
  • The client must not explicitly modify (eSet) meta models or install new ones. The meta models are read-only and reserved for use by the implementation of the Client API.
  • As always, everything in Java packages with "internal" in the name is strictly off limits.

Implementation note: There is no requirement that the nice API provided for an extended item type bear any direct relationship to the underlying EMF objects.

Parameters:
clazz - the desired Java class; must not be null
Returns:
an instance of clazz, or null if this item could not be so adapted

equals

boolean equals(java.lang.Object o)
Returns whether the given object is the same item as this item.

This method is implemented as Java object identity (==) for all item handles (and items).

Design note: equals() is defined this way due in part to EMF restrictions on the underlying objects (EMF objects cannot redefine equals).

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
o -
Returns:

size

long size()
Returns an approximation of the size in bytes of this object plus the objects it references.

Returns:
the size in bytes of this object plus the objects it references.
